coredata.dc:title: Direct force calculation in the Xα method and its application to chemisorption of an oxygen atom on the Al(111) surface

(15) The force/^(l) between the charged atoms is a long- range interaction. The force between the non-over- lapping atoms can be approximated by the point charge interaction. The derivative of the total energy with respect to the fifh nuclear coordinate R is given by F^ = -9E/9R^ = F^(l) + ^(2) , (9) where F^(l) is the Hellmann Feynman term W) = -^ S Z^R^/R^+Z^ FpO-^/^du (10) and F^(2) comes from the derivative of the wavefunc- tion with respect to R^ 112 This force is a short-range interaction between the overlapping atoms. This decomposition of^(l) and ^(2) is useful for calculations on a many-atom sys- tem. The force /T (3) is due to the Xa exchange corre- lation potential v^: ^(3) = 3 / [(dp^/dr)?^ - (dp^dr)p^] X i^eO-)?-1 du . The decomposed force /-r has the following character- istics: fT =-f Jft JT (17) (18) Volume 83, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 October 1981 This corresponds to the action and reaction relation- ship between the /zth and Tth atoms. It is evident from this relationship that the total force is guaran- teed to be zero. The antisymmetnzed form of the force /J reduces some of the errors in the following numerical calculation. We have written a program to calculate the force in the Xa theory. First we solve self-consistently the HFS Xa equation (4) to obtain the HFS wavefunc- tion. The decomposed forces are calculated from eqs. (12)-(17) using this HFS wavefunction. The HFS and force matrix elements are numerically evaluated. The integration space is divided into Wigner Seitz cells around each atom. The integration within each cell is done by the gaussian quadrature and the angular quadrature methods [10], for the radial and angular directions, respectively. The detailed method of cal- culation will be reported elsewhere. 3. Geometry optimization of an oxygen atom on the Al( 111) surface The chemisorption of an oxygen atom on Al(l 11) has been studied by many theoretical and experimen- tal methods. The oxygen atoms are chemisorbed in the three-fold centered hollow sites [11]. The posi- tions of the oxygen above the Al(l 11) surface deter- mined so far are summarized in table 1. These values are different from each other. The value determined by EXAFS seems to be most reliable. As the first test of our calculation, we studied the bond distance of a molecule A10. We calculated the force acting between the Al and 0 with the numerical basis of the neutral Al(ls22s2 '2.p63s23p) and Table 1 Bonding distance of oxygen above theAl(lll) surface Method Bonding distance (au) Ref. jelhum model 33 [12] first-order pseudo-potential 15 [13] LEED analysis 2.51 [14] EXAFS analysis 132 [15] SW calculation and UPS experiment 1.0-2.0 [16] present calculation 100 OCls^s2^?4). We obtained the equilibrium bond dis- tance as 3.07 au; the experimental value is 3.05 au [17]. In this letter we report the results for the unrelaxed surface model which corresponds to the monolayer coverage of the oxygen atom. The initial coverage of oxygen induces relaxation of the aluminum around the chemisorbed site of the oxygen. The monolayer coverage weakens the relaxation due to the interaction between the stress around the chemisorbed sites. We chose the tetrahedral Al4 cluster as a model of the Al(l 11) surface. The A1 A1 bond distance was taken as the unrelaxed value 5.41 au of the metal [18,191. We calculated the force as a function of the position of the oxygen atom above or below the center of the Al3 triangle. The calculated force acting on the oxygen atom, the first layer AI(1) and the second layer Al(2) is shown in fig. 1. The position of zero force acting on the oxygen atom was found at 1.0 bohr above the un- relaxed surface. This value is in better agreement with the EXAFS experiment than the other calculations shown in table 1. From the position dependence of the force we can divide the chemisorption mechanism into three steps. The first step is in the region farther away from equilibrium. The oxygen has an attractive interaction with the first layer aluminum and weakly interacts with the second layer. The second step is in the region from the equilibrium distance to the sur- face layer (/? = 0.0 au). The strong interaction be- Fig 1. The calculated force acting on the chemisorbed 0, the first layer AI(1) and the second layer Al(2). The positive (negative) force is defined to be in the direction out of (into) the surface. The positive (negative) height corresponds to the position above (below) the surface. 113 Volume 83, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 October 1981 -1012 HE1 GHT (a u ) Fig. 2 The potential curve of the chemisorbed oxygen atom tween the oxygen and the surface layer aluminum breaks the bond between the first and the second layer. The third step starting around the position at R^ = OS au is within the transition region in which the attractive force between the oxygen and the se- cond layer aluminum begins to make a significant con- tribution to the force acting on the oxygen. The total binding energy can be obtained by inte- gration of the force along the coordinate. The result for the oxygen is shown in fig. 2. Two minima exist, one on the outside and the other on the inside of the surface. The outside minimum is deeper by ==0.5 eV than the inside minimum. The photoemisaon spectrum from the Al 2p core state has shown that with an in- crease in temperature the oxygen atom gains the energy necessary to penetrate the surface and to become a bulk-like aluminum oxide. The activation energy for this change has been obtained from analysis of the peak intensity as ^s 1 eV [20]. This value is com- parable to the present calculated barrier height 0.84 eV. However, penetration may occur simultaneously with the thermal relaxation of the surface. For a quan- titative discussion on the activation energy we must consider the effect of the surface relaxation. 4. Concluding remarks We have demonstrated that the force analysis elu- cidates the chemisorphon process of the oxygen on Al(l 11). The stresses on the Al atoms around the ad- sorbed oxygen were determined directly. It is difficult to obtain these stresses from the total energy calcula- tion. Though the size of our cluster model may be small for a quantitative analysis of the surface, we have obtained a reasonable bond distance of the oxygen on the Al surface. The potential energy curve was ob- tained from integration of the force vector. It is promising to apply this force analysis to the study of the equilibrium configuration of the surface atom, the adsorbed atoms and the atoms around the defect on the surface. We are also studying the disso- ciative chemisorption with this method. Results of such calculations will be reported elsewhere. Acknowledgement The author is grateful to Professor M. Tsukada and Dr. S. Kato of this institute for helpful discussions and comments. Numerical calculations have been car- ried out at the Computer Center of this Institute on a HITAC M-200 computer.
